prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I kick my adult ”stepdaughter” out of my house?
New here so if I haven’t understood one of the rules please let me know!

I have a tricky situation I’m going through as of late.  I’m in a long term relationship.  We aren’t technically married, but we live as we are.  After a messy divorce she was never interested in being married again.  We’ve been dating for 8 years now.  I told her that the engagement is the best part so I proposed with both of us understanding that we would never actually get married.  She has an adult daughter who lives with us.  She’s 19. 

My “stepdaughter” and I have never had a good relationship despite my best efforts.  I really gave it everything I could to improve it over the years, but at best she was indifferent to me.  I gave up trying after buying her a car for her 16th birthday and she thanked her mother and didn’t acknowledge me at all even after her mother told her that I alone bought it for her.  

After that I’ve been just waiting her out for the most part.  I’m still kind when I’m around her, but if this is the relationship with me she wants then so be it.  I always assumed that when she turned 18 she would go off to school somewhere.  I was unfortunately wrong.  She instead started working at a salon in town.  She had taken cosmetology in BOCES in high school.  

I thought once she had been working for a bit and had saved enough she would then move out.  Wrong again.  I’ve asked her mother to see what her plans are for the future and if she plans on moving out on her own soon and my wife told me that she just wants to save as much as she can and keep living here.   My fiancé loves having her here, but I’ve been waiting so long to have the house be just my fiancé and I.   

I really feel like I’ve put my time in supporting her daughter and now especially with her having more than enough to move out on her own it’s time to push her out of the nest.  I’m not too concerned with her reaction.   To be blunt I don’t really care how she takes it.   My fiancé will probably be a little upset, but hopefully once the dust clears she will see that it’s for the best.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. The situation is that the author is in a long-term relationship with his fiancé, who he's not married to but live together. Their daughter's 19-year-old stepdaughter still lives at home. The stepdaughter and the author have a strained relationship; he tried hard to build a connection but she was indifferent. He bought her a car for her 16th, but she thanked the mother only. Now she's working and could afford to move out, but she's staying. The author wants her to leave to have the house to himself and his fiancé.

First, legal aspects. In most places, once a child turns 18, they're adults, and the parents aren't legally obligated to support them. However, if the child is still in school or has no income, they might stay, but in this case, the stepdaughter is working. The author isn't her biological parent, so he might not have legal authority to make her leave. But since they live together and she's an adult, she can choose to stay. Legally, he can't force her out without her consent or legal means, like an eviction, which might require a lease agreement. Since it's a roommate situation, he might need to give notice or go through an eviction process, which could be complicated if she's an adult.

Ethically, the author's motives are clear: wanting privacy with his partner. But he's not her parent, so pushing her out might be seen as selfish. However, he's not the one providing financial support; her mother (his fiancé) might be. The stepdaughter is an adult, so she has the right to choose where she lives. If she's not causing problems, maybe the author is overstepping. But if their relationship is hostile, maybe she's not a good fit for the household. However, the author's approach of being indifferent and then wanting to kick her out could be seen as harsh. He should consider communication, maybe setting boundaries, or discussing the situation with her directly instead of just deciding unilaterally.

His fiancé's role is also important. Since she supports the stepdaughter living there, the author should consider their relationship dynamics. If he goes ahead without her full agreement, it could cause marital issues. The author's lack of concern for her reaction is a red flag. Also, the stepdaughter might feel betrayed if she's been staying because she felt supported by her mother and the author.

So, putting it all together: The author is in a complicated situation. Legally, if he's not her parent, he can't just kick her out without process. Ethically, he's prioritizing his own desires over her autonomy. Even though the relationship is bad, the approach is abrupt and possibly harmful. The stepdaughter might have her own reasons for staying, and the author isn't considering her perspective. Therefore, the author is in the wrong because he's not handling the situation with the necessary care and legal/ethical considerations.
